title: Soft-Field Takeoff and Climb
objectives: Minimize aircraft weight on landing gear during taxi and takeoff
Achieve liftoff at minimum safe airspeed
Accelerate in ground effect before climbing
overview: Soft-field takeoffs are essential for operations from grass, mud, snow, or unpaved surfaces. This lesson teaches techniques to minimize weight on the landing gear and use ground effect to accelerate before climbing.

instructorActions: Explain soft-field conditions: grass, mud, gravel, snow
Discuss: 'Keep weight off landing gear by holding elevator back'
Show technique: continuous motion from taxi to takeoff
Demonstrate with model: pitch attitude during ground roll
Brief: 'Lift off early, accelerate in ground effect, then climb'
keyPoints: Continuous motion - don't stop on soft surface
Elevator back during taxi and takeoff roll
Early liftoff uses ground effect advantage

instructorActions: Taxi with elevator full back: 'Keeping weight off nose wheel'
At runway: 'Smoothly add full power without stopping'
Narrate: 'Holding elevator back... feel it getting light'
Liftoff: 'Lifting off early... staying in ground effect'
Accelerate: 'Accelerating to VY... now climbing away'
Explain: 'Ground effect gave us that extra performance'
Coach: 'Keep that elevator back... smooth power'
Prompt: 'Feel it getting light? Let it fly'
During ground effect: 'Stay low... accelerate... now climb'
Monitor for premature climb-out
Praise good technique: 'Perfect weight management there'
studentActions: Lift off at minimum safe airspeed
Accelerate in ground effect before climbing
keyPoints: Feel for the airplane wanting to fly
Don't force it off early or hold it on too long

keyTeachingPoints: Soft-field technique minimizes landing gear stress
Elevator back during taxi keeps weight off nose wheel
Add full power smoothly without stopping
Lift off at minimum safe airspeed (near stall)
Stay in ground effect to accelerate to VY
Ground effect extends to about 1 wingspan altitude
After reaching VY, establish normal climb
Use 10° flaps if POH recommends for soft-field
commonErrors: Stopping on soft surface - sinking in
Not keeping elevator back - nose wheel digs in
Forcing airplane off before flying speed
Climbing immediately after liftoff - settling back
Not using ground effect for acceleration

diagrams.title: Soft-Field Technique
diagrams.description: Continuous motion from taxi through climb
diagrams.asciiArt:
Taxi: [Elevator BACK]
  ↓
Roll: [Full power, elevator back]
  ↓
Lift: [Early liftoff at min speed]
  ↓
Ground Effect: [Accelerate to VY]
  ↓
Climb: [Normal climb at VY]

completionStandards.standard: Lift off at lowest safe airspeed
Accelerate in ground effect to VY
Maintain VY +5/-0 knots after clearing obstacles

notes: Ground effect is dramatic on soft fields
instructorNotes: Watch for student rushing the liftoff
safetyConsiderations: Brief what to do if airplane won't accelerate
Don't attempt if surface too soft
Watch for nose wheel damage if technique poor

title: Soft-Field Approach and Landing
objectives: Touch down at minimum descent rate
Avoid nose wheel contact with soft surface
overview: Soft-field landings require touching down at minimum descent rate and keeping weight off the nose wheel. Students learn to use power throughout the approach, gentle touchdown technique, and taxi procedures on soft surfaces.

instructorActions: Explain soft-field landing goal: minimum descent rate, minimum roll
Discuss: 'Power is used right up to touchdown for control'
Show: 'After touchdown, hold elevator back to protect nose wheel'
Brief: 'Don't stop after landing - keep moving'
Narrate: 'Normal approach but power is key control'
On final: 'Approach speed... controlling descent with power'
Threshold: 'Small power reductions... flare gently'
Touchdown: 'Mains touch softly... holding elevator back'
Rollout: 'Nose stays up... keep moving... taxi clear'
Explain: 'Never stopped - continuous motion protects from sinking'
Coach approach: 'Use power for descent control'
Near touchdown: 'Gentle... gentle... softest touchdown possible'
After landing: 'Elevator back... keep moving'
Monitor for hard touchdown or nose wheel contact
keyPoints: Power management is finesse, not large movements

keyTeachingPoints: Soft-field landing minimizes descent rate and landing distance
Use power throughout approach for precise descent control
Touch down at minimum controllable airspeed
Flare is gradual and power stays on longer than normal
Main wheels touch first (nose high attitude)
Hold elevator back after touchdown - protect nose wheel
Continue taxiing - don't stop on soft surface
Use recommended flap setting from POH
commonErrors: Removing all power too soon - hard touchdown
Landing nose wheel first - potential damage
Not holding elevator back on rollout
Stopping on soft surface after landing
Too fast on approach - floating and firm landing

diagrams.title: Soft-Field Landing Profile
diagrams.description: Power management throughout approach and landing
diagrams.asciiArt:
Approach: [Power ON for control]
  ↓
Flare: [Gradual power reduction]
  ↓
Touchdown: [Soft touchdown, elevator BACK]
  ↓
Rollout: [Elevator back, keep moving]

completionStandards.standard: Touch down at minimum safe airspeed
Touch down with minimum descent rate

instructorNotes: Student may land flat at first - normal
safetyConsiderations: Ensure soft field is safe for operations
Brief go-around if surface too soft
Be ready to take controls if hard landing imminent

title: Slip to a Landing
objectives: Transition from slip to normal landing
Understand when to use slips vs flaps
overview: Slips are intentionally uncoordinated maneuvers used to steepen descent or correct for crosswind. This lesson covers forward slips (for descent) and sideslips (for drift correction), emphasizing the difference and proper technique for each.

instructorActions: Draw forward slip diagram: bank one way, rudder opposite
Explain: 'Forward slip steepens descent without adding airspeed'
Show sideslip: 'Keeps longitudinal axis aligned with path'
Demonstrate with model airplane
Discuss when slips are useful: too high without flaps, crosswind
Brief POH limitations: some aircraft prohibit slips with flaps
keyPoints: Bank creates descent, rudder controls track
Check POH - some prohibit slips with full flaps

instructorActions: On approach: 'We're high - I'll demonstrate forward slip'
Execute: 'Bank left... right rudder to maintain centerline'
Narrate: 'Steep descent now... airspeed stable'
Recovery: 'Neutralizing... back to coordinated flight'
Explain: 'Increased drag from slip profile caused steep descent'
Set up student high on approach
Coach: 'Bank left... right rudder... hold it'
Monitor altitude loss rate
Before landing: 'Recover to coordinated flight'
Ensure student checks POH limits

keyTeachingPoints: Forward slip: bank and opposite rudder to steepen descent
Sideslip: maintains longitudinal axis alignment (crosswind)
Slip increases drag - steep descent without airspeed increase
More aggressive slip = steeper descent
Recovery: neutralize controls to coordinated flight
Must recover before landing - land coordinated
Check POH: some aircraft prohibit slips with flaps extended
Slips useful when: too high, no/limited flaps, crosswind correction
commonErrors: Not using enough bank/rudder - insufficient slip
Landing while still in slip - side loads on gear
Not checking POH for slip limitations

diagrams.title: Forward Slip Mechanics
diagrams.description: Bank creates descent, opposite rudder maintains track
diagrams.asciiArt:
Normal Descent:  →→→
Forward Slip:    ↘↘↘ (much steeper)
                 ← Bank left, rudder right

notes: Crosswind practice days are perfect for slips
instructorNotes: Some students nervous about uncoordinated flight
safetyConsiderations: CRITICAL: Check POH for slip limitations with flaps
Recover to coordinated flight before touchdown
Be alert for stall at low altitude
